frame.name: Coming_to_believe
frame.definition:
<def-root>A person (the <fen>Cognizer</fen>) comes to believe something (the <fen>Content</fen>), sometimes after a process of reasoning. This change in belief is usually initiated by a person or piece of <fen>Evidence</fen>. Occasionally words in this domain are accompanied by phrases expressing <fen>Topic</fen>, i.e. that which the mental <fen>Content</fen> is about.
<ex><fex name="Evidence">Based on the most recent census</fex> <fex name="Cognizer">I</fex> have <t>concluded</t> <fex name="Content">that most Americans sleep too much</fex>.</ex>
<ex></ex>
<asf>ASFALDA French FrameNet comment</asf>: The reasoning from some Evidence or through some Means is the key aspect of that frame, to distinguish it from <frframe>FR_Becoming_aware</frframe>. Contrary to the above definition, for the LUs of that frame, the change in belief cannot be initiated by another person (which is the case for <frframe>FR_Cognizer_affecting.veracity</frframe>).
<ex></ex> Distinctions with other frames: <ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>FR_Becoming_aware</frframe>: Evidence is only a core role for Coming_to_believe: FR_Becoming_aware's LUs do not imply that the Cognizer's stance on the Content was based on anything, whereas Coming_to_believe's do.
<ex></ex> ≠ <frframe>FR_Cognizer_affecting.veracity</frframe>: Coming_to_believe's Cognizer's stance cannot be initiated by a human volitional source, whereas FR_Cognizer_affecting.veracity's can.
<ex> </ex> ≠ <frframe>FR_Awareness-Certainty-Opinion</frframe>: Coming_to_believe is inchoative of FR_Awareness-Certainty-Opinion, which is a stative frame.
</def-root>

FE.name: Cognizer
FE.definition: <def-root>Cognizer is the person who comes to believe something. <fex name="Cognizer">Sue</fex> <t>realized</t> that Bob was lost. </def-root>

FE.name: Evidence
FE.definition: <def-root>Words in this frame may occur with a PP headed by <ment>from</ment> which expresses the Evidence on which knowledge or belief is based: I have <t>learned</t> <fex name="Evidence">from experience</fex> that poison oak can be painful. </def-root>

FE.name: Content
FE.definition: <def-root>With a target verb, the Content is usually expressed as a finite clausal Complement or an Object NP, and may sometimes be expressed by a PP: The President <t>learned</t> <fex name="Content">that the reporters were hungry</fex>. The children <t>determined</t> <fex name="Content">the answer</fex>. </def-root>

FE.name: Topic
FE.definition: <def-root>Some verbs in this frame may occur with postverbal Topic expressions: They <t>found out</t> <fex name="Topic">about us</fex>! More generally verbs in this frame may occur with quantificational nouns followed by Topic expressions: The jury <t>learned</t> something terrible <fex name="Topic">about the suspect</fex>. </def-root>

FE.name: Means
FE.definition: <def-root>An act performed by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> which enables them to figure something out. <ex><fex name="Means">A post-mortem examination</fex> was unable to <t>ascertain</t> the cause of death.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Medium
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Medium</fen> is the text created by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> to communicate that they came to believe a specified <fen>Content</fen>.</def-root>
